query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
1 Lo giorno se n’andava, e l’aere bruno 2 toglieva li animai che sono in terra 3 da le fatiche loro; e io sol uno
4 m’apparecchiava a sostener la guerra 5 sì del cammino e sì de la pietate, 6 che ritrarrà la mente che non erra.
query.result:
**English:**
1 The day was departing, and the dusky air 2 was taking away the animals that are on earth 3 from their labors; and I alone
4 was preparing myself to endure the battle 5 both of the journey and of pity, 6 which the mind that does not err will recall.
**Cornish:**
1 An dedh o partia, ha’n awel tewl 2 a gavas an enevales syw yn an bys 3 a’ga gwriansow; ha my a-unan
4 o parya dhe wul an golghi an vresel 5 a’n fordh ha’n kevri, 6 an poynt a wra’n an menowgh na wra fal.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
7 O muse, o alto ingegno, or m’aiutate; 8 o mente che scrivesti ciò ch’io vidi, 9 qui si parrà la tua nobilitate.
query.result:
**English:**
7 O Muses, O lofty genius, now help me; 8 O memory that wrote down what I saw, 9 here your nobility will be revealed.
**Cornish:**
7 O muses, o uchel spyrys, wrewgh vyth mosow; 8 o menowgh a skrifas an peth a welas, 9 ena wra’th golghas dha nobeli.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
10 Io cominciai: «Poeta che mi guidi, 11 guarda la mia virtù s’ell’ è possente, 12 prima ch’a l’alto passo tu mi fidi.
query.result:
**English:**
10 I began: "Poet who are guiding me, 11 consider my powers, whether they are strong enough, 12 before you trust me with the difficult task.
**Cornish:**
10 My a dhallathas: “Bardh a wra’m gorra, 11 sel an pow a’m boes, 12 kyns na’m gorra gans an fordh kresek.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
13 Tu dici che di Silvïo il parente, 14 corruttibile ancora, ad immortale 15 secolo andò, e fu sensibilmente.
query.result:
**English:**
13 You say that the ancestor of Silvius, 14 still mortal, went to the immortal 15 age, and was there in bodily form.
**Cornish:**
13 Thy a leverel bos Silvïus, 14 marowek, dhe vos dhe’n bys heb marow, 15 ha bos gans korf ynno.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
16 Però, se l’avversario d’ogne male 17 cortese i fu, pensando l’alto effetto 18 ch’uscir dovea di lui, e ’l chi e ’l quale
19 non pare indegno ad omo d’intelletto; 20 ch’e’ fu de l’alma Roma e di suo impero 21 ne l’empireo ciel per padre eletto:
22 la quale e ’l quale, a voler dir lo vero, 23 fu stabilita per lo loco santo 24 u’ siede il successor del maggior Piero.
query.result:
**English:**
16 Therefore, if the adversary of all evil 17 was courteous to him, considering the great effect 18 that was to come from him, and who and what he was,
19 it does not seem unworthy to a man of understanding; 20 for he was chosen in the empyrean heaven as the father 21 of noble Rome and of her empire:
22 which, to tell the truth, was established by the holy place 23 where the successor of the greatest Peter sits.
**Cornish:**
16 Mes, mar an gwithyas a bub drok 17 a veu dhe’n garow, ow tressa an effeyth uhel 18 a dheuth dhe vos a-dhyworth, ha’n pyw ha’n peth
19 nyns eus anvos dhe dhen a spyrys; 20 rag ev a veu a-dhyworth yn an nef a-ucha 21 avel tas a Rom ha’y empir:
22 an peth ha’n pyw, dhe leverel an gwir, 23 a veu sevelhes gans an le maynek 24 le mayr Pêr a wra’n y’n ertach.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
25 Per quest’ andata onde li dai tu vanto, 26 intese cose che furon cagione 27 di sua vittoria e del papale ammanto.
query.result:
**English:**
25 Because of this journey, for which you praise him, 26 he heard things that were the cause 27 of his victory and of the papal mantle.
**Cornish:**
25 A-rag an fordh hemma le mayth thy’n garow, 26 ev a glewas pethow a veu an acheson 27 a’y vykteri ha’y ammanth pab.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
28 Andovvi poi lo Vas d’elezïone, 29 per recarne conforto a quella fede 30 ch’è principio a la via di salvazione.
query.result:
**English:**
28 Then went the Vessel of Election, 29 to bring comfort to that faith 30 which is the beginning of the way of salvation.
**Cornish:**
28 Wosa henna ev eth Vas a etholans, 29 rag dhe gorra gorhemmans dhe’n feyth hemma 30 a’n poynt dhe fordh a’n fordh a’n salvacyon.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
31 Ma io, perché venirvi? o chi ’l concede? 32 Io non Enëa, io non Paulo sono; 33 me degno a ciò né io né altri ’l crede.
query.result:
**English:**
31 But why should I go there? Or who permits it? 32 I am not Aeneas, I am not Paul; 33 neither I nor anyone else believes me worthy of this.
**Cornish:**
31 Mes my, rag hemma dhe vos dhe dhyski? po pyw a’m gorra? 32 My nyns eus Enëa, my nyns eus Pol; 33 my nyns eus dhegys dhe hemma, ha neb aral.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
34 Per che, se del venire io m’abbandono, 35 temo che la venuta non sia folle. 36 Se’ savio; intendi me’ ch’i’ non ragiono».
query.result:
**English:**
34 Therefore, if I abandon myself to the journey, 35 I fear that my coming will be foolish. 36 You are wise; understand me, for I am not speaking rashly."
**Cornish:**
34 Rag hemma, mar my a omdhisk dhe dhyski, 35 my a omdhisk na vo an dhos dhe fol. 36 Thy’th fur; komprehendya my, rag my nyns eus ow leverel yn fol.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
37 E qual è quei che disvuol ciò che volle 38 e per novi pensier cangia proposta, 39 sì che dal cominciar tutto si tolle,
40 tal mi fec’ ïo ’n quella oscura costa, 41 perché, pensando, consumai la ’mpresa 42 che fu nel cominciar cotanto tosta.
query.result:
**English:**
37 And like one who changes his mind about what he wanted 38 and alters his plan because of new thoughts, 39 so that he abandons the whole thing from the beginning,
40 so I did on that dark hillside, 41 because, thinking, I gave up the enterprise 42 that was so difficult to begin.
**Cornish:**
37 Ha kepar ha nen a wra’n ow lettya an peth a vynnas, 38 ha rag nowyth spyrysow a wra chanjya y’n breder, 39 kepar na wra gorfenna an peth a-dhyworth an kynsa,
40 hemma o wrug my yn an kodha tywyll hemma, 41 rag, ow tressa, my a omdhisk an ober 42 a veu kemmys dhe dhyski yn an kynsa.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
49 Da questa tema acciò che tu ti solve, 50 dirotti perch’ io venni e quel ch’io ’ntesi 51 nel primo punto che di te mi dolve.
query.result:
**English:**
49 In order to free you from this fear, 50 I will tell you why I came and what I heard 51 at the first moment that I felt sorry for you.
**Cornish:**
49 Rag an dowethma ma na vyth vyth dhe'th solvi, 50 vyth a leveris dhys orth pyth dhe wrugav vy dhe'th klevyas 51 y'n kynsa poynt pan owth vyth dhe'th dholvi.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
52 Io era tra color che son sospesi, 53 e donna mi chiamò beata e bella, 54 tal che di comandare io la richiesi.
query.result:
**English:**
52 I was among those who are suspended, 53 and a lady called me blessed and beautiful, 54 so that I asked her to command me.
**Cornish:**
52 Y'm mysk o'n dus a veu dhe'n suspedys, 53 ha benen a leveris dhym bethys ha brav, 54 kepar henna owth vyth dhe'm gwaynya dhe'm commandi.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
55 Lucevan li occhi suoi più che la stella; 56 e cominciommi a dir soave e piana, 57 con angelica voce, in sua favella:
58 “O anima cortese mantoana, 59 di cui la fama ancor nel mondo dura, 60 e durerà quanto ’l mondo lontana,
61 l’amico mio, e non de la ventura, 62 ne la diserta piaggia è impedito 63 sì nel cammin, che vòlt’ è per paura;
64 e temo che non sia già sì smarrito, 65 ch’io mi sia tardi al soccorso levata, 66 per quel ch’i’ ho di lui nel cielo udito.
query.result:
**English:**
55 Her eyes shone brighter than the stars; 56 and she began to speak to me softly and gently, 57 with an angelic voice, in her own language:
58 "O courteous Mantuan soul, 59 whose fame still endures in the world, 60 and will endure as long as the world is far away,
61 my friend, and not of fortune, 62 is hindered in the deserted plain 63 so much on the way that he has turned back out of fear;
64 and I fear that he may already be so lost 65 that I may have risen too late to his aid, 66 because of what I have heard about him in heaven.
**Cornish:**
55 Y'n golwg ow lowenhe moy es an steren; 56 ha hy a dhallathys dhe'm leverel marthys ha platta, 57 gans leuv avel, y'n yeth hy honan:
58 "O eneval dhe'n Vantua curteis, 59 pyth yw aga hanow bythkweth y'n bys, 60 ha bythkweth byth pan yw an bys pell,
61 aga cara, ha na'ga'n fortشن, 62 y'n an garrek dyghow yw lettys, 63 mar owth vyth y'n fordh, dell yw dro dhe'n keus;
64 ha owth vyth owth vyth aga owth vyth kellys, 65 pan owth vyth owth vyth owth vyth owth vyth dhe'm dhe'n skoos, 66 rag an pyth ow klevyas dhe'n nef."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
67 Or movi, e con la tua parola ornata 68 e con ciò c’ha mestieri al suo campare, 69 l’aiuta sì ch’i’ ne sia consolata.
query.result:
**English:**
67 Now move, and with your eloquent speech 68 and with what is necessary for his survival, 69 help him so that I may be consoled.
**Cornish:**
67 Wosa movy, hagena dha lavar ornat 68 hagena an pethow re beu campare, 69 an geus sy dhe'n vyfyn consolata.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
73 Quando sarò dinanzi al segnor mio, 74 di te mi loderò sovente a lui”. 75 Tacette allora, e poi comincia’ io:
76 “O donna di virtù sola per cui 77 l’umana spezie eccede ogne contento 78 di quel ciel c’ha minor li cerchi sui,
79 tanto m’aggrada il tuo comandamento, 80 che l’ubidir, se già fosse, m’è tardi; 81 più non t’è uo’ ch’aprirmi il tuo talento.
query.result:
**English:**
73 When I am before my lord, 74 I will often praise you to him.” 75 Then she was silent, and then I began:
76 “O lady of virtue alone through whom 77 the human species surpasses every delight 78 of that heaven which has the smallest circles above it,
79 your command pleases me so much, 80 that to obey it, if it were already possible, would be late for me; 81 I desire nothing more than for you to reveal your wish to me.
**Cornish:**
73 Pyth vythfya yn keverel vyth argluydh, 74 A'th leverel vyth a-dro dhetho. 75 Hi a-dheuth taws, hagena my a-dhallethas:
76 “O benen a-ugh dhe bys vyth onen 77 An den a-ugh dhe bys owth omma oll pleser 78 A'n nef a-ugh an cylgh hag y'n byghan,
79 Kemmys yw vyth leverel dheth ommandyans, 80 Ha'm ugens, mar o ve, vyth dhewedh dhe'm, 81 Nyns eus dheth omma moy es dheth leverel dhe'm.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
82 Ma dimmi la cagion che non ti guardi 83 de lo scender qua giuso in questo centro 84 de l’ampio loco ove tornar tu ardi”.
query.result:
**English:**
82 But tell me the reason why you do not protect yourself 83 from descending down here into this center 84 of the vast place where you burn to return.”
**Cornish:**
82 Mes leverel dhe'm an acheson na'th gwyly 83 A-dhybri orth a-ugh yn-ma yn-meneth-ma 84 A'n le brassa le a'th eus ankow a-dhybri.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
85 “Da che tu vuo’ saver cotanto a dentro, 86 dirotti brievemente”, mi rispuose, 87 “perch’ i’ non temo di venir qua entro.
query.result:
**English:**
85 “Since you want to know so deeply, 86 I will tell you briefly,” she replied to me, 87 “why I do not fear to come down here.
**Cornish:**
85 “Rag as eus owth gallas kemmys dhe wodhya, 86 Y'th leverel dhe'th yn berr, a-dheuth dhe'm, 87 Rag na'm eus owen a-dhybri a-mena.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
88 Temer si dee di sole quelle cose 89 c’hanno potenza di fare altrui male; 90 de l’altre no, ché non son paurose.
query.result:
**English:**
88 One should only fear those things 89 that have the power to harm others; 90 not the others, for they are not fearsome.
**Cornish:**
88 Dyllo wra dhe dheth omma anedha 89 A-ugh an gallu dhe wul ober dhe'n erel drok; 90 A'n erel, rag na'ns eus owen dhe dheth omma.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
91 I’ son fatta da Dio, sua mercé, tale, 92 che la vostra miseria non mi tange, 93 né fiamma d’esto ’ncendio non m’assale.
query.result:
**English:**
91 I am made by God, through his grace, such 92 that your misery does not touch me, 93 nor does the flame of this fire assail me.
**Cornish:**
91 Y'm gwres gans Duw, dre y rudh, marow, 92 Ha'th anken na'm teuth dhe'm, 93 Ha tan an tan-ma na'm teuth dhe'm.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
94 Donna è gentil nel ciel che si compiange 95 di questo ’mpedimento ov’ io ti mando, 96 sì che duro giudicio là sù frange.
query.result:
**English:**
94 There is a gentle lady in heaven who grieves 95 over this impediment where I am sending you, 96 so that harsh judgment is broken up there.
**Cornish:**
94 Benen yw yn nef a-ugh owth kompassi 95 A'n lettyans-ma a'm eus owth kas dhe'th, 96 Marow bys dheth breus an breus a-ugh.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
97 Questa chiese Lucia in suo dimando 98 e disse:—Or ha bisogno il tuo fedele 99 di te, e io a te lo raccomando—.
query.result:
**English:**
97 Lucia asked this in her request 98 and said: "Now your faithful one has need 99 of you, and I commend him to you."
**Cornish:**
97 An benen-na, Lucia, a-dheuth an pyth ommandyans 98 Ha'n leverel:—An-drò owth eus anken dhe'th feythful 99 A-ugh, ha my a-dheuth dhe'th dhe'n.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
100 Lucia, nimica di ciascun crudele, 101 si mosse, e venne al loco dov’ i’ era, 102 che mi sedea con l’antica Rachele.
query.result:
**English:**
100 Lucia, enemy of every cruel one, 101 moved herself and came to the place where I was, 102 where I was sitting with the ancient Rachel.
**Cornish:**
100 Lucia, an gowes dhe bubel kruelek, 101 A-dheuth ha'n dheuth dhe'n le a'm eus, 102 A'm eus owth sevel gans an hen Rachel.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
103 Disse:—Beatrice, loda di Dio vera, 104 ché non soccorri quei che t’amò tanto, 105 ch’uscì per te de la volgare schiera?
106 Non odi tu la pieta del suo pianto, 107 non vedi tu la morte che ’l combatte 108 su la fiumana ove ’l mar non ha vanto?—.
query.result:
**English:**
103 She said: "Beatrice, true praise of God, 104 why do you not help the one who loved you so much, 105 that he left the common crowd for you?
106 Do you not hear the pity of his weeping, 107 do you not see the death that fights him 108 on the river where the sea has no power?"—
**Cornish:**
103 Hi a leveris:—Beatrice, gwir vorthyans Dew, 104 peragga na'th skoedhyas an ke a garas dhodho, 105 hag a dheuth magh dhyworth an bagas kemmyn rag dhis?
106 Na'th klev an trues a'y glewas, 107 na'th gwels an marow a'y teves 108 war an avon le may'n mor an gorth y'n powes?—

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
109 Al mondo non fur mai persone ratte 110 a far lor pro o a fuggir lor danno, 111 com’ io, dopo cotai parole fatte,
112 venni qua giù del mio beato scanno, 113 fidandomi del tuo parlare onesto, 114 ch’onora te e quei ch’udito l’hanno”.
query.result:
**English:**
109 In the world there were never people so quick 110 to do themselves good or to flee from harm, 111 as I was, after such words were spoken,
112 to come down here from my blessed seat, 113 trusting in your honest speech, 114 which honors you and those who have heard it.
**Cornish:**
109 Yn an bys na veu bythquoi dus tus 110 rag ober aga gwel po rag fethe aga drok, 111 dell yw ow, wosa geirieu avel henna,
112 a dheuth ama omma dhyworth ow sedh bennak, 113 ow fya yn aga lavar onest, 114 a wraga onour dhys ha'n re a'y klev.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
115 Poscia che m’ebbe ragionato questo, 116 li occhi lucenti lagrimando volse, 117 per che mi fece del venir più presto.
query.result:
**English:**
115 After she had spoken this to me, 116 she turned her shining eyes, weeping, 117 so that she made me come more quickly.
**Cornish:**
115 Wosa henna leverel dhyn, 116 hi a droeis aga lagad skednys, 117 rag henna hi a wrug dhom dheuth moy a-varra.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
118 E venni a te così com’ ella volse: 119 d’inanzi a quella fiera ti levai 120 che del bel monte il corto andar ti tolse.
query.result:
**English:**
118 And I came to you just as she wished: 119 I took you away from that beast 120 that kept you from the short path to the beautiful mountain.
**Cornish:**
118 Ha dheuth dhys dell yw ow a garas, 119 owth skonya dhyworth an best magh 120 a lettis dhyworth an fordh berr dhe'n menydh brav.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
121 Dunque: che è? perché, perché restai, 122 perché tanta viltà nel core allette, 123 perché ardire e franchezza non hai,
124 poscia che tai tre donne benedette 125 curan di te ne la corte del cielo, 126 e ’l mio parlar tanto ben ti promette?».
query.result:
**English:**
121 So then: what is it? Why, why did you stop, 122 why do you harbor so much cowardice in your heart, 123 why do you not have courage and boldness,
124 since three such blessed ladies 125 care for you in the court of heaven, 126 and my words promise you so much good?
**Cornish:**
121 Dell yw henna: pyth yw? Peragga, peragga a lettis, 122 peragga kemmys cowardis yn aga golon, 123 peragga na'th corys ha frankis,
124 wosa teyr bennak magh an tair gwregoryon bennak 125 a wraga ow sel yn leas an nef, 126 ha'm lavarow ow promett dhys kemmys da gwel?

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
127 Quali fioretti dal notturno gelo 128 chinati e chiusi, poi che ’l sol li ’mbianca, 129 si drizzan tutti aperti in loro stelo,
130 tal mi fec’ io di mia virtude stanca, 131 e tanto buono ardire al cor mi corse, 132 ch’i’ cominciai come persona franca:
133 «Oh pietosa colei che mi soccorse! 134 e te cortese ch’ubidisti tosto 135 a le vere parole che ti porse!
136 Tu m’hai con disiderio il cor disposto 137 sì al venir con le parole tue, 138 ch’i’ son tornato nel primo proposto.
query.result:
**English:**
127 Like little flowers bowed and closed 128 by the night frost, then, when the sun whitens them, 129 they all straighten up, open on their stems,
130 so I became, my strength exhausted, 131 and such good courage ran through my heart 132 that I began to speak like a bold person:
133 "Oh, she who pitied me and helped me! 134 And you, courteous one, who quickly obeyed 135 the true words that she spoke to you!
136 You have so disposed my heart with desire 137 to come, with your words, 138 that I have returned to my first intention.
**Cornish:**
127 Dell yw bleujyow byghan a veu pleget gans an jel nos 128 ow plegya ha kews, wosa an howl a'y gwynn, 129 a sevel oll ow blossom war aga stel,
130 henna yw ow a wrug, ow virtu ow fetha, 131 ha kemmys corys da a redya omma golon, 132 henna yw ow a dhallathsa dell yw person frank:
133 "Oh, an hini trues a skoedhas dhom! 134 Ha tiso, owth ostyas a-varra 135 dhe'n geirieu gwir a leveris dhys!
136 Tys a wraga ow colon ow sel gans yns 137 rag dheuth gans aga geirieu, 138 henna yw ow a dhroes dhe'n kynsa propos.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
139 Or va, ch’un sol volere è d’ambedue: 140 tu duca, tu segnore e tu maestro». 141 Così li dissi; e poi che mosso fue,
142 intrai per lo cammino alto e silvestro.
query.result:
**English:**
139 Now go, for our will is one: 140 you be my guide, my lord, and my teacher." 141 Thus I said to him; and after he had set out,
142 I entered the high and wild path.
**Cornish:**
139 Dell yw henna, kerensa sol yw genen ny dhew: 140 tys ow tyak, tys ow arloedh ha tys ow mester." 141 Dell yw ow a leveris dh'agan; ha wosa henna a veu movyas,
142 ow a eth drefen an fordh ughel ha gwyls.
